articles.headline: The Washington Post Delves Into a Difficult Story: Itself
articles.snippet: The newspaper has been reeling from successive revelations about Robert Winnett, its incoming editor, and Will Lewis, its chief executive.
articles.abstract: The newspaper has been reeling from successive revelations about Robert Winnett, its incoming editor, and Will Lewis, its chief executive.
articles.lead_paragraph: The backyard goodbye party for Sally Buzbee, the recently departed executive editor of The Washington Post, was beginning to break up on Sunday evening when the newspaper published a critical investigation into her permanent successor.
articles.byline: By Benjamin Mullin and Katie Robertson

articles.headline: Israel Pauses Daytime Offensive in Part of Gaza, Raising Hopes for More Aid
articles.snippet: The new policy, addressing concerns that combat made aid delivery too dangerous, took hold as an increasingly isolated Benjamin Netanyahu dissolved his war cabinet.
articles.abstract: The new policy, addressing concerns that combat made aid delivery too dangerous, took hold as an increasingly isolated Benjamin Netanyahu dissolved his war cabinet.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Israeli military said on Monday that it had paused operations during daylight hours in parts of the southern Gaza Strip, as a new policy announced a day earlier appeared to take hold, along with cautious hopes that it would allow more food and other goods to reach desperate civilians.
articles.byline: By Patrick Kingsley, Adam Rasgon, Cassandra Vinograd and Michael Levenson

articles.headline: A Korean Secret to Keeping Friendships Strong: Savings Groups
articles.snippet: In South Korea, it’s common for friends to form what are known as gyemoim to save for vacations, meals and other social activities.
articles.abstract: In South Korea, it’s common for friends to form what are known as gyemoim to save for vacations, meals and other social activities.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last fall, Jina Kim and two of her friends splurged on a two-night stay at the Ananti at Busan Cove, a luxury resort in Busan, South Korea.

articles.headline: The Gun Lobby’s Hidden Hand in the 2nd Amendment Battle
articles.snippet: Case after case challenging gun restrictions cites the same Georgetown professor. His seemingly independent work has undisclosed ties to pro-gun interests.
articles.abstract: Case after case challenging gun restrictions cites the same Georgetown professor. His seemingly independent work has undisclosed ties to pro-gun interests.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the battle to dismantle gun restrictions, raging in America’s courts even as mass shootings become commonplace, one name keeps turning up in the legal briefs and judges’ rulings: William English, Ph.D.
articles.byline: By Mike McIntire and Jodi Kantor

articles.headline: Trump’s ‘Wartime Consigliere’ Now Faces Legal Peril of His Own
articles.snippet: Boris Epshteyn routinely surfaces as a lesser character in Trump-related indictments. In a case in Arizona, he pleaded not guilty on Tuesday to nine felony charges.
articles.abstract: Boris Epshteyn routinely surfaces as a lesser character in Trump-related indictments. In a case in Arizona, he pleaded not guilty on Tuesday to nine felony charges.
articles.lead_paragraph: Boris Epshteyn, who was arraigned Tuesday on election interference charges in Arizona, has played many roles for former President Donald J. Trump.
articles.byline: By Danny Hakim, Alan Feuer and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Biden’s Stimulus Juiced the Economy, but Its Political Effects Are Muddled
articles.snippet: Some voters blame the American Rescue Plan for fueling price increases. But the growth it unleashed may be helping the president stay more popular than counterparts in Europe.
articles.abstract: Some voters blame the American Rescue Plan for fueling price increases. But the growth it unleashed may be helping the president stay more popular than counterparts in Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: The $1.9 trillion economic stimulus package that President Biden signed shortly after taking office has become both an anchor and a buoy for his re-election campaign.
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley and Madeleine Ngo

articles.headline: Biden Gives Legal Protections to Undocumented Spouses of U.S. Citizens
articles.snippet: The new policy is one of the most significant actions to protect immigrants in years. It affects about 500,000 people who have been living in the United States for more than a decade.
articles.abstract: The new policy is one of the most significant actions to protect immigrants in years. It affects about 500,000 people who have been living in the United States for more than a decade.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Biden on Tuesday granted far-reaching new protections for hundreds of thousands of immigrants who have been living in the United States illegally for years but are married to American citizens.
articles.byline: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Miriam Jordan, Jazmine Ulloa and Hamed Aleaziz

articles.headline: How the Teamsters and a Homegrown Union Plan to Take On Amazon
articles.snippet: An affiliation agreement between the Amazon Labor Union and the 1.3 million-member Teamsters signals an escalation in challenging the online retailer.
articles.abstract: An affiliation agreement between the Amazon Labor Union and the 1.3 million-member Teamsters signals an escalation in challenging the online retailer.
articles.lead_paragraph: After years of organizing Amazon workers and pressuring the company to bargain over wages and working conditions, two prominent unions are teaming up to challenge the online retailer.

articles.headline: Israel and Hezbollah Play a Risky Tit-for-Tat, Leaving Region on Edge
articles.snippet: A full-scale war could devastate both Israel and Lebanon, where the Hezbollah militia is a far better trained and equipped adversary than Hamas.
articles.abstract: A full-scale war could devastate both Israel and Lebanon, where the Hezbollah militia is a far better trained and equipped adversary than Hamas.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the war has raged in Gaza, another battle has unfurled in parallel along Israel’s northern border with Lebanon — a risky game of tit-for-tat that has intensified in recent weeks, with a far stronger foe.
articles.byline: By Aaron Boxerman and Hwaida Saad

articles.headline: Boeing C.E.O. Apologizes for Quality and Safety Issues at Senate Hearing
articles.snippet: Confronted by families of those killed on two flights, Dave Calhoun, Boeing’s chief executive, apologized for “the grief that we have caused.”
articles.abstract: Confronted by families of those killed on two flights, Dave Calhoun, Boeing’s chief executive, apologized for “the grief that we have caused.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Shortly after Boeing’s chief executive, Dave Calhoun, took his seat, families who lost relatives in the 2018 and 2019 crashes of the company’s 737 Max 8 planes called out to him, demanding that he turn around and acknowledge them and the photos of their loved ones.
articles.byline: By Mark Walker, Maya C. Miller and Niraj Chokshi
